subtitles_text: >> JEFF: Previously on
Survivor, Keith and Tina plotted to take down Jerri.
>> TINA: She's the most bossy, domineering person I've ever
met. >> KEITH: I didn't come out here
to be pushed around by a bartender-wannabe-actress.
>> JEFF: Jerri persuaded Colby to make a deal.
>> COLBY: It's me, you and Amber, through to the end.
>> JERRI: It's not like you're making a deal with the devil
here. >> COLBY: I simply agreed to go
along with them to get me down the road a little better.
>> JEFF: Kimmi's morals were compromised when the tribe won
chickens in a reward challenge. >> KIMMI: Don't break her wings,
though. Can't they give us some edamame,
some tofu...? >> JEFF: Michael shocked his
tribe by killing a pig. >> KIMMI: We live in a sick
tribe. >> ELISABETH: We're going to get
strong now. >> JEFF: Kucha continued their
winning streak by taking the immunity challenge, sending
Ogakor back to Tribal Council for the third consecutive time,
where the vote was deadlocked in a double tie between Keith and
Mitchell. One vote is the difference.
But ultimately it was Mitchell who was voted out, putting a
dent in Jerri's hopes for an alliance.
12 are left. Who will be voted out tonight?
( birds chirping ) >> COLBY: We really started
noticing the smoke and hearing the trees explode and crash.
Uh, yesterday, I guess, is when it got the closest to us.
And now we're just completely pretty much overtaken by smoke.
>> AMBER: My eyes are watering. >> TINA: It's just extremely
hazy and smoky, and... It's an interesting morning.
>> AMBER: We've had an interesting past couple of days,
as far as, uh... Let's see, our last Tribal
Council we lost Mitchell, which was a surprise.
>> JERRI: It was a pretty... pretty traumatic evening.
I think our little group of common voters has been busted
up. It's a whole new ball game right
now. >> KEITH: Love this game.
>> JERRI ( half-whispering ): Tina and Keith are definitely
grouped together, but Colby is like the one in the middle,
like... >> AMBER: They're totally
grouping together. >> JERRI: Everybody else is
trying to pair up, or they're trying...
We're all vying for Colby's vote.
>> COLBY: I'm playing from the center, dude.
I'm playing from... ( Keith laughing )
Let's squash this one. >> AMBER: Seems like since Tina
was able to get Colby to sway his vote last time and vote for
Mitchell, seems like maybe he, uh, might sway again to their
side. But we're almost kind of
fighting over him. >> COLBY: What we did was
strategic, and it was to help the team out, and I know it did
that. >> JERRI: I have, you know...
I'm not harboring any ill feelings whatsoever about the
whole deal. We still are more powerful if
the three of us are voting the same.
>> COLBY: I'm still voting just like I did last night, based on
who the strongest... who I think's got what it takes to
make it in. Maybe tomorrow, I might be
thinking a whole lot different, but... right now I'm not.
>> JERRI: I mean, it's basically the end of any alliance, pretty
much. >> COLBY: Jerri, I don't care.
I don't care about that stage of it.
I mean, all I care about is doing everything we can to win
the next two immunity challenges.
That's the only thing I can focus on right now.
>> KIMMI: Good morning, stinkies.
We gotta clean you out, 'cause you all stink.
Last night was a very uncomfortable sleeping night.
It was drafty, it was cold. Nobody slept last night.
Like, it was just like one of those nights where anything and
everything that could wake you up did.
>> JEFF V.: I woke up once, and there was a hot coal on my
shirt-- look. >> RODGER: You're kidding?
>> JEFF V.: And there was a little fire in my wooly.
>> NICK: Whew! >> ALICIA: "Fire in my woolly."
That's not the first time I heard that.
Well, how the hell did it bypass everybody else in front
of you? >> JEFF V.: I don't know, but if
it came all the way back here, it could have landed on your
face. >> MICHAEL: That's exactly
right. >> JEFF V.: Know what I'm
saying? >> ALICIA: That's not funny.
>> JEFF V.: It's not funny. The fire had been popping coals
out of the fire onto us. >> ALICIA: Wow.
>> JEFF V.: So, we had to move our fire this morning.
It just was getting a little too dangerous.
>> KIMMI: Very good chickens. They're very happy now.
Hello, hello... >> JEFF V.: We got fire!
>> RODGER: It was a little inconvenient right there, you
know, but boy, late at night, nighttime, be...
Gonna be different around there when it gets cold at night.
I guess we're ready to go. Chicken killing time.
>> ALICIA: You know what, though?
That hatchet needs to be sharpened.
It's pretty dull again. >> RODGER: Mike got the pig,
and, uh, we ate real good. We wasn't able to save all the
meat, so I guess we're going to eat chicken.
So, we won't have the eggs. ( scraping continues )
Sharp as possible while we're... while we're doing the chicken
in. >> KIMMI: Hello, ladies.
I have such brilliant hens over here, yes...
>> MICHAEL: I just tell Kimmi, "For your own self-preservation,
let go of the chicken thing. Stop talking about them, stop
getting involved..." >> KIMMI: What's going over
>> NICK: We're building a fire to boil water, to kill the
chicken. ( clucking )
>> KIMMI: Well, that's my cue. >> MICHAEL: Yeah, we're ready.
>> KIMMI: See you later, bye. >> MICHAEL: Stop making a big
spectacle when you leave. "Oh, you're butchering the
chickens, I'm out of here!" Da-da-da-da-da!
You know, I mean, it's just... It's too theatrical, it's just
too much. >> KIMMI: Bye, chickies,
bye-bye. >> MICHAEL: I'm ready.
I'm feeling the need to shed some blood.
>> ALICIA: Whatever. ( indistinct voices )
>> RODGER: I don't... I don't, I don't enjoy killing animals,
neither. >> ELISABETH: Sure.
>> RODGER: I don't, really, but sometimes, nobody wants to do
it. Jeff, you want to do it?
>> MICHAEL: I thought Jeff wanted to do it.
>> ELISABETH: Maybe next time. >> RODGER: You got it?
( pounding, moaning ) >> ELISABETH: I like that.
Get these feathers off. >> JEFF V.: Oh, they're hot.
>> RODGER: Yeah, this is by far the right...
>> ELISABETH: Good stuff. That chicken's going to be so
awesome... >> ALICIA: It's gonna be so
good. ( indistinct voices )
>> AMBER: Thank you. >> KEITH: You're welcome.
>> AMBER: The food situation could definitely be better.
It could always get better. We're not eating that much at
all. We're definitely not eating as
much as the other tribe is. >> JERRI: When you come to see
me, we have to go somewhere and get a really good pizza.
>> AMBER: Okay. >> JERRI: And lots of garlic and
bread... We haven't caught any fish for,
I think, two days now. The whole hunger thing, that for
me has been a huge hurdle. Keith, did you disassemble some
of these for the line the other night?
The only ones that are rigged to go are the cricket and the
silver one. >> KEITH: Jerri went to go
fishing, and she needed the can. And of course, she hollered out
to me, like her older sibling. >> JERRI: What do you suggest we
do with the fish guts? >> KEITH: I said we'll take them
to the end and dump them in the water, like we've been doing it.
And so, she brought them down to the water's edge down at the end
of camp to dump them out, and then she yelled back that it's
not a smart idea to dump them in there, because...
>> JERRI: We're literally feeding the fish every time we
dump the guts down there. >> KEITH: Well, my vote is you
just bury them in the sand down by the end down there.
>> JERRI: The thing is, it's also downwind from us, so once
they start rotting, if by chance you get a second, if you want
to... >> KEITH: I'll bury them.
>> JERRI: Yeah? >> KEITH: No problem.
>> JERRI: That would be really cool.
>> KEITH: It's all right. I'm thinking on these couple
hundred acres of water, I'm not sure that a few fish eating some
dead fish is going to matter a whole lot, but whatever.
>> JERRI: It's just ridiculous to me to continue to dump the
guts at the end of our beach. We're literally feeding the
fish. It's no wonder we haven't been
able to catch anything, they're all full.
>> KEITH: It's not that big of a deal, but apparently...
it was. I don't stand up to her that
often, 'cause I don't find it necessary, 'cause it's more
exhausting to argue with her than anything.
The fish... are now... buried. Dead fish.
>> JERRI: We haven't been catching fish again, and the
other team is eating chickens and pigs and eggs, you know.
And here we are over here, starving to death.
>> KEITH: You have any? >> JERRI: No luck.
Those are the things that I didn't really think going into
this that were going to bother me.
But it has. >> KIMMI: ...something really
different. >> ALICIA: No, no, I didn't get
upset about you; I left. >> KIMMI: No, my point is, is
that with the, uh, chicken, I'm just saying for these guys to
stay stronger, it's better to, like, do every other day,
putting meat in their body. >> ALICIA: You gotta be kidding?
>> KIMMI: I don't know. >> ALICIA: We're active every
day, we need protein every day. >> KIMMI: No, my points is...
>> ALICIA: That's not a good argument, it's not gonna work.
>> KIMMI: This isn't like a debate to be arguing about.
>> ALICIA: No, I know. >> KIMMI: I'm just saying...
>> ALICIA: But I'm telling you why I don't agree with you.
That's exactly the point. >> KIMMI: Okay, well, you don't
have to agree with me. >> ALICIA: And I don't.
So, there you go. >> KIMMI: Okay, fine.
>> ALICIA: I'm tired of the chickens, tired of it.
>> KIMMI: Excuse me? >> ALICIA: Do you have some kind
of a problem? >> KIMMI: Yeah, I have a problem
with your attitude. >> ALICIA: Oh really!?
>> KIMMI: What the hell is up your butt?
>> ALICIA: What you just said is not true.
We should be having protein every day.
If we have to have the chickens, we will.
>> KIMMI: I'm just saying, if you had the chickens here...
>> ALICIA: Right! You see us going fishing, right?
>> KIMMI: You can go... That's all I was saying-- it's a
good just thing to break it up, especially...
>> ALICIA: You are the defensive one about the chickens, not me,
so do not yell at me about the chickens.
>> KIMMI: I am not getting emotionally attached.
>> ALICIA: You can get as emotionally attached as you
want. Because the only reason why we
said it is 'cause we care about your feelings 'cause you're part
in this tribe. But don't jump all over me,
sweetheart, don't ever... >> KIMMI: But the thing is, I'm
not getting upset. Don't wave your finger in my
face. >> ALICIA: I will always wave my
finger... >> KIMMI: And mumble under your
breath. >> ALICIA: You want me to say it
to your face? >> KIMMI: Yes, if you have...
>> ALICIA: Yes, I will be happy to.
I'm saying it to your face right now.
>> KIMMI: Thank you! >> ALICIA: I'm tired of you and
the... chickens-- you heard it! >> KIMMI: What have I said about
the chickens, though? Nothing! That's the problem.
>> ALICIA: Please, you and your little...
( didgeridoo playing ) >> KIMMI: She has more of an
issue with the chickens than I do.
Gosh! >> ALICIA: I don't really
appreciate her to begin with, so for me to try to walk away from
a situation I know is potentially going to turn ugly,
and her not to let me do that, made me want to just run up and
grab her by the throat. But I-I had to keep my wits
about me, because that's not what this is about.
>> JEFF V.: What did I just miss? I was peeing?
>> ALICIA: Plenty. I've never liked Kimmi, we all
know that. So when she jumps on me, I will
go at her guns loaded, okay? >> JEFF V.: What did she say,
though? I totally missed it.
What happened? >> ALICIA: Sitting on the floor
of the house, she goes... >> KIMMI: Alicia has always had
a problem with me. She said, "Kimmi, don't get too
attached to the chickens." I'm like, "I'm not getting
attached to the chickens." Like, don't worry!
I'm a big girl. I said, "You know, while we have
the chickens here we shouldn't just eat four chickens and a pig
back-to-back days. >> ALICIA: I said, "You know
what, Kimmi? This is why we didn't want you
to get emotionally attached to the chickens."
That's all I said. >> KIMMI: She's very critical of
other people, she's very condescending of other people,
and I will not be treated, um, you know, like a jerk-off.
>> ALICIA ( scoffing ): Give me a break.
If you're going to make sense, you can say whatever you want to
me, but if you're not going to make sense, keep your mouth
shut. >> JEFF V.: I knew that that
Alicia/Kimmi explosion was coming, I knew it was coming.
Kimmi was befriending the chickens and giving them names
and petting them. And, um, Alicia just has no
patience. Alicia doesn't have a lot of
patience for anybody, really. >> ALICIA: I had enough, and I
let loose, baby. >> ELISABETH: Alicia is in
charge of telling people to do things.
Alicia is also in charge of talking trash about people.
>> ALICIA: We still have to stay together as a team.
>> ELISABETH: We do. >> ALICIA: So I'm willing to
live and let live. >> KIMMI: I just think it was a
silly misunderstanding. But we all are on the same team,
so we gotta... at least have a poker face on for game day, I
suppose. ( birds squawking )
>> NICK: This fire doesn't throw off the heat that the other fire
did. >> ALICIA: This is the only
time, though, when the fire really stinks, you know...
>> NICK: We moved the fire pit away from our camp for some
safety reasons. And we had it nice and close--
about five feet from where we all sleep, so it was really warm
at night. But we moved it away, and last
night was really, really cold. >> RODGER: Coldest night for me.
Whew! >> NICK: You know, what can we
do? We don't have any blankets, so
then we just bundle up. >> ALICIA: Come on over to the
fire. >> RODGER: Cold on that
outside... >> MICHAEL: Let me tell you, it
was cold on the inside, so if it was cold on the inside...
>> RODGER: Oh... >> KIMMI: The water here grosses
me out more than anything. This Crocodile Creek is food and
bathroom to fish and crocodiles and birds and bats, and, you
know all kinds of algae and bacteria.
And it's just... I don't know, I just find it to be incredibly
gross. >> MICHAEL: Kimmi, I don't know
if she's been in the water once, and... the dirt's starting to
stick to her. >> KIMMI: But also 'cause you
can see my tan line-- look at it.
>> MICHAEL: You know, some, one of the other girls puts on a
different top, you'll see a tan line.
When Kimmi puts on a different top, you'll see a dirt line.
>> KIMMI: I washed yesterday. >> MICHAEL: You changed clothes.
I mean, your neck is, like, filthy.
>> KIMMI: Filthy, well be... Oh, because I was carrying tree
stuff today. That's why my neck is filthy.
>> MICHAEL: And then she got real defensive about it.
I said "I'm..." I said, "If I had a booger hanging out of my
nose, and you told me about it, I would say 'thank you.'
I wouldn't get all mad at you." >> KIMMI: That's nice.
>> MICHAEL: I mean, it's not bad.
I mean, we're all dirty. >> RODGER: Whew!
>> ELISABETH: It's a big one! >> NICK: Is it FedEx?
>> ELISABETH: Feels like a package.
>> NICK: Wow. >> ELISABETH: It's a book!
>> NICK: It's a catalog. >> ELISABETH: Check this thing
out! >> MICHAEL: That is stylin'!
>> KIMMI: Wow! >> ELISABETH: Okay, "You must be
prepared when your tribe's in a bind.
Build a travois, and save their behinds..."
>> JEFF V.: Build a what? >> ELISABETH: Build a tra...
>> NICK: A stretcher thing. >> ELISABETH: Like a stretcher
"...and save their behinds. Look through this book.
You can only choose two. Plus from your friends at
Target... clean teeth and shampoo!"
>> KIMMI: Shampoo! Oh! >> ELISABETH: Oh, my God, you
guys! >> NICK: We get to pick two
things, we get to pick two things.
>> ELISABETH: Okay, boxers and slippers?
>> KIMMI: No. >> ELISABETH: We'll skip that
page. Toilet paper?
>> NICK: Blankets, we need blankets.
>> ELISABETH: Blankets I think is one, don't you?
>> RODGER: Blankets would be... >> ALICIA: Blankets would be
wonderful, 'cause we really-- now that we moved our fire...
>> MICHAEL: I think we're all... >> ALICIA: ...we really have an
issue with that. >> ELISABETH: Yeah.
>> RODGER: Everybody wants the spices?
>> ELISABETH: Oh, it is a catalog...
>> RODGER: Raise your hand. Everybody wants spices who...
what do you want? Spices? I'll go with spices.
>> ELISABETH: The two items that we chose... we definitely need
blankets. Last night was really cold.
I had a miserable night's sleep. I don't know if anyone really
slept through, especially without our fire out here, it's
so cold. We are going to choose for the
second item spices, and we get toothpaste and shampoo when we
win this today. >> ALICIA: "Travois."
They're using some French words. >> NICK: A stretcher.
>> ALICIA: It's a stretcher, to carry somebody in.
>> MICHAEL: Look how they show the thing, though.
It's not like what you'd think. It's a teepee... it's a
triangle. >> ALICIA: Yeah, it's a tri...
>> ELISABETH: Wow! >> NICK: We have to make one of
these, you guys. So, how are we going to build
this thing? Let's think.
>> KIMMI: Yes? >> ALICIA: We could even make
something out of rope for her feet to sit in.
>> ELISABETH: We could have add- ins, like a pillow...
>> RODGER: If we use that bamboo pole, how are we going to tie
onto that? >> ALICIA: Those up there are
going to start to cross. >> KIMMI: Is that real hard
wood? >> ELISABETH: That can go right
under my butt. >> JEFF V.: That's the width.
We want the length. >> MICHAEL: Keep it tight where
you guys had it, at the top. >> RODGER: Can you come around
this and tie a bunch of slipknots in?
>> ELISABETH: Is that on your head?
>> KIMMI: Yeah, but that's okay. >> ALICIA: We're gonna need it
for the back corner... >> RODGER: Are your legs still
where you can reach the corners? Or you need to slide down a
little bit? >> ALICIA: Rock solid.
>> MICHAEL: One, two, lift. ( Elisabeth laughs )
>> ALICIA: Feels stable enough? >> KIMMI: Mm-hmm.
>> ELISABETH: Whee! >> RODGER: All right, we got it
down. >> ELISABETH: I think over at,
uh, Ogakor, they're probably trying to pull it together
really well. We have to go out there as if
we're facing a tribe just as strong as we are.
>> AMBER: Who's gonna decide do we want to make it like a
rectangle...? >> JERRI: All right, here, give
me the goods, then just hold... You hold onto that end, and as I
weave it just follow-follow me with this.
>> COLBY: We're dragging this thing.
We want the least amount of friction we can get.
>> JERRI: Okay, so what's your point?
What's wrong with this? >> COLBY: I'm saying...
>> JERRI: Do you see what I'm doing with this, though?
>> COLBY: Exactly, and I think it's great.
I'm saying instead of starting it over the top, start it
underneath. >> AMBER: From underneath.
>> COLBY: You see what I'm saying?
>> KEITH: We got two pieces... >> JERRI: No, I don't see what
you're saying. You guys want to, like, put her
in it and pick it up-- the four of us-- just to see what
happens? I got kind of tickled when
making the travois. I knew that the idea I had would
work, and everybody was just kind of standing around and
talking. And no one was doing anything.
So I just kind of grabbed the bull by the horns.
God bless America... this... >> KEITH: I have probably a
little more patience than Colby does.
But I can usually tell when he's getting a little tense and a
little agitated, you know. He'll walk away from it and just
take a breath. >> JERRI: Let's try it this way,
just in case we're able to. >> AMBER: Is it really bad?
>> JERRI: Yay, it works! >> TINA: Ooh!
>> JERRI: Oh! >> COLBY: The toughest part for
this tribe is coming into these challenges with our guns
blazing, ready to rock. We gotta win this thing, and we
still got a shot at doing it. >> JEFF: Come on in, guys.
All right, well, we've already established how tough it is
living in the Outback. You're battling-- among other
things-- an out of control fire, wildlife, crocodiles, snakes,
spiders. If you get hurt, you are a long
way from help. You have to be able to rely on
your tribe mates to get you back to safety.
That's where today's challenge comes in: triage.
You were asked to build a travois-- a three-sided
stretcher. You're going to use that today.
Two members from each tribe will be the rescuers.
Three members will be the victims.
You'll be placed at three different spots out here on the
river on little sand spits. There's a flag designating the
area. There is a circle around that
flag. The victims will stand inside
that circle. When the rescuers get out there,
you get on your travois and you head back.
Once they cross this line and they're okay, they are
miraculously healed, they become a rescuer.
Now you have three. Going for the next person.
First tribe to get all three of their victims back to the first
aid camp wins reward. Now, Kucha, because you guys
have two extra members, two people will sit out.
The winning tribe gets what they wanted and also what the other
tribe wanted. ( all groaning )
>> ELISABETH: Shut up! >> JEFF: So, Kucha, you chose
the blankets and the spices. Ogakor, you also chose the
spaces and the soup mix. >> ALICIA: It's a beautiful
thing. >> JEFF: And Target has thrown
in a few other items. They're not necessities, these
are luxuries. Got fresh toothbrush...
( murmuring ) >> AMBER: Oh, my gosh!
>> JEFF ...toothpaste, deodorant.
>> RODGER: Oh, yeah, we could use that.
>> JEFF: And of course, what every survivor needs, shampoo.
( all cheering ) >> ELISABETH: Wow!
>> AMBER: Oh, my God. >> ELISABETH: That's awesome.
>> JEFF: Okay, you guys decide who is going to sit out.
Decide on your rescuers and your victims.
Wait for my start. >> TINA: Go, Ogakor!
Come on, guys! >> JEFF: Kimmi and Rodger,
you're sitting out for Kucha. A lot of reward at stake.
Survivors, ready... Go!
>> TINA: Go, go, go, go! >> Dude, come here.
>> Go, go, go, go, go! Pick it up!
>> KIMMI: Go, Kucha! >> ALICIA: Guys, push, push,
push, push, push! Get ahead!
( team members yelling ) >> ELISABETH: Kucha!
>> JERRI: Ogakor! ( yelling, shouting )
>> RODGER: You're ahead! ( yelling, shouting )
>> MICHAEL: Walk through! >> ELISABETH: Okay, okay.
>> Good job, Kucha! >> RODGER: Good job, all right!
>> JEFF: Congratulations. Nice job, Kucha.
>> It's all yours. >> Good job.
>> JEFF: Here we go, guys. >> NICK: Here's blankets.
>> RODGER: All right. ( happy shouting )
>> All right, all right. >> AMBER: I'm just so tired of
losing. ( sniffling, crying )
>> TINA: Don't let 'em break your spirit now.
>> COLBY: I am getting very frustrated with losing.
If we don't turn up the heat and turn this runaway train around,
then it may be a meltdown for the Colbster.
>> TINA: It's not the things you lose, it's just losing.
You know, it takes such a psychological hit on your
already psychologically tired body that, for our team, it's
definitely the loss that hits us hard.
>> ALICIA: Winning the reward challenges is, basically, just
one more nail in the coffin. Not as important as immunity,
but another thing that's gonna sink them just a little bit
lower. >> JEFF V.: I don't mean to
sound evil, but it's all about kicking somebody's ass.
>> ALICIA: There's no way they're gonna give up.
They were very graceful losers, actually.
I'm just so glad we're not them right now.
That's rough. >> JEFF V.: Some of the people
in the tribe are talking about how guilty they feel and how bad
they feel for the other tribe-- and screw it!
I mean, chop their heads off, chop their legs off, this is a
game and I'm ready to beat every one of them.
I'm ready to chop their heads off and their eyeballs out so
Mike can eat them... ( laughter )
>> JEFF V.: I stink. >> ELISABETH: Me, too.
>> ALICIA: Toothpaste and toothbrush and shampoo and
deodorant. I'm not going to know what to do
with myself. >> ELISABETH: Oh, my gosh!
Shampoo that doubles as soap. >> JEFF V.: Let's go wash.
>> MICHAEL: Everybody else smells out here, but everybody
else bathes. Thank God we won that challenge,
so that we can bathe Kimmi. >> MICHAEL: Group bath.
We won the reward challenge yesterday and we used the
shampoo-- we each got a handful, and we just all soaped up,
'cause the camp was getting a little stinky.
Some more than others, because some people bathe more than
others around here-- but it was fun.
>> RODGER: You've got to prove that.
( laughter ) >> AMBER: We got mail!
"This next challenge will prove harder than the rest,
You'll be rats in the maze for this little test.
Just keep your wits and you'll make it with ease,
The prize is the idol and that's much better than cheese."
>> JERRI: Oh, a maze! >> AMBER: I think we should have
a little pep talk. Well, I think... today, I don't
think it's our strength is going to get us through this
challenge. I honestly think it's our minds
and our hearts, and if we all believe we can do it.
I definitely think we can. So just make sure that you don't
doubt your heart and your mind at all today, and I think that
will get us through it. >> JERRI: There's a lot of
pressure on us today-- a lot. But let's not forget also to
have fun with this. >> COLBY: It is going to take
every ounce of keenness, of smarts, of strength, of
everything we have. The excuses are done, check them
at the door and let's get down to business.
It is going to be one hell of a show today and it's... you know,
I think we're as ready as we're going to be.
>> JERRI: All right, Ogabkor. Here we go!
Let's do this! >> JEFF: I'll take that.
Once again, give it up, Varner. The immunity idol is back up for
grabs. Here's the deal today:
A giant maze. 46 tons of lumber, three miles
